yusraakdeniz: I love this! I suffer from anxiety and deal with it. Even if it sometimes breaks my heart... ☺
southwesternstyling: You’re a true trailblazer to attempt to normalize this thing. For me they will never be shiny gold letters that I’ll accept, they’ve wreaked havoc, limited me, isolated and embarrassed me. I never want to excuse myself of my behavior and blame that because I don’t think people have the capacity, patience or ability to understand so I usually just disappear for a while after a work related episode. These are hard words to choke down and accept. I could accept that I was an alcoholic and I could stop. But I can’t just stop this. And I’m 💯 responsible for my behavior and actions and yet not completely in control of them. I think it’s thought provoking but if we were to where all our diseases on are chest as scars.. my trauma feels minuscule when I see a man begging for money with one leg and talking to himself riddled with ptsd. I think it’s great and I wish you success in a Hope story that will not just normalize that we are all living in these conditions but that you’ll share tools that have helped you along the way 💋💕👍

lisforleslie123: Should we all just start chanting “re-stock” “re-stock” “re-stock”?!
katiezoe: Amazing. About two months ago I walked into my dr’s office to talk with her about my mental health. Not only had I not showered in 3 days, but I was wearing the same yoga pants and sweater I hadn’t changed out of in 3 days. I had taken on clients who needed very clear boundaries communicated and I wasn’t in a mental space to create those boundaries, so every time the multitudes of texts and emails came through from them I only got more anxious. I was in the waiting room, filling out the quick checklist analysis of what level of depression I was feeling when an email popped up and I burst into tears. I had been drinking and eating to excess, gaining 30 lbs, a number on the scale I had only seen during pregnancy. The only reason I didn’t score the highest number on the depression screening was because, while many days I laid in bed thinking I could easily never move my body again, I never wanted to actually be dead and leave my children. I’ve since responded really well to the medication I was prescribed and feel capable and hopeful. It’s been an eye-opening experience, also brought on after a divorce, but took years and a few more heavy events to get to a place where I realized I was not okay and didn’t know how to get okay again. Thank you for speaking out. It was so important to me to start watching videos of people describing how they felt with anxiety and depression and identifying the symptoms that I was feeling as well. I felt less alone in the vast darkness of depression. ❤️❤️

sliceoflimephoto: Your bravery in tackling these topics with such openness and rawness and humor is just, wow. So needed. Thank you.
edencreature: Terrible concept that continues to stigmatize mental illness by making it an accessory. Notice how only two “acceptable” illnesses are used. Where’s the schizophrenia necklace? The bpd necklace? An anorexia necklace? They don’t exist because those illnesses aren’t as easy to de-stigmatize as acidity and depression. People wear those two like accessories all the time and it does nothing but further the romanticized version of them we see in the media. Shame on bando for using illness as a way to accessorize and belittle mental health awareness.

gypsysoulqueen: Just found you because of @edroste ❤ I've had anxiety and depression since I was a kid. I wanted to get help but the 12 steps wasn't for me. Unfortunately the treatment center went bankrupt and I lost my job. I've been working on creative projects to raise awareness and hopefully encourage healing for others. I'm a musician, artist, and dancer..and use these outlets for myself and hopefully inspire others. @grizzlybear has been a huge inspiration for me and I find their music is far better for my well being than an hour in therapy. katenelsononline: @jengotch I bought a planner from @shopbando at the beginning of this school year (my 8th cumulative year in pursuit of just one BA), hoping it would add some light & fun to my last year of college, the journey to which has been full of anxiety, depression, self harm and under it all, undiagnosed ADD. On my worst days, pulling out my laptop and notebooks felt impossible, but pulling out my planner first, with its mantra “One Day at a Time” written across the front, has helped me so much more than I ever thought it would. At my lowest points, the cheerful and inspiring messages inside have genuinely cheered me up and have beat back the loud, cruel inner voice I can never seem to shake. I support you forever and ever and ever and I am so grateful for all you do to de-stigmatize these illnesses, and I love you endlessly for the honestly and integrity that you lead your life and your business with. Thank you ❤️
